_prev_prog_2.Description:
Everything in this prevention program applies to the TDI process, which is considered a single process. 



A compilation of written process safety information was used in conducting the hazard analysis (HA). The process safety information included information pertaining to the hazards of TDI, information pertaining to the technology of the TDI process, and information pertaining to the equipment utilized in the TDI process. The HA was conducted using the methodology specified in 40 CFR 68.67 (What If).  A system has been established to promptly address the findings from the methodology used.



The operating procedures are consistent with the process safety information and address steps for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety systems, and their functions.



Training for employees associated with the TDI process is provided along with required refresher training.



A preventive maintenance program is utilized to ensure ongoing mechanical program of the TDI process.



Compliance audits of the Risk Management Program is conducted every three (3) years to verify that procedures are adequate and are being followed.



Any incident involving the TDI process and equipment will be investigated.  The facility will consult with affected employees on the conduct and development of the elements of the management of th TDI process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

FXI, Inc. - Brenham is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of TDI is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

FXI, Inc.is a urethane foam manufacturing facility which produces various type of flexible urethane foam products located in Brenham, Texas. The facility fabricates some of the urethane foam into various finished products.

Flexible urethane foam is a product made by combining various chemicals that undergo a chemical reaction. The finished product is produced in a variety of colors, thicknesses, and densities.  One of chemicals used is 2, 4-Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI). The TDI is stored in three (3) storage tanks; (1) 10,000-gallon, and (2) 5,000-gallon TDI Storage Tanks within the tank storage area.  At times TDI is also stored in an 20,000 gallon railcar until loading occurs.  Therefore, the total combined physical volume onsite is approximately 40,000 gallons.

The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to a process storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is Toluene 2, 4-Diisocynate (TDI) in excess of 10,000 pounds which is used as an ingredient in the manufacturing process.

After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process.  Based on the Off Site Consequence Analysis, facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subje

ct to Program 2 of the RMP regulations.



B.  Accidental Release Prevention and Specific Prevention Steps:

FXI, Inc.is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards.  An appropriate response to releases of TDI is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 

FXI, Inc.'s specific prevention steps include:

1. Hazard reviews to identify, evaluate and control potential TDI process hazards,

2. Develop, review and update operating and maintenance procedures for the TDI process.

3. Provide the appropriate training for TDI process operators, maintenance personnel, and emergency response personnel.

4. Conduct timely investigations of all incidents involving the TDI process.

5. Conduct RMP Compliance audits as per RMP regulations.



C. Hazard Assessment:

The RMP requires FXI, Inc.to evaluate the maximum potentially affected area for accidents involving TDI for a worst case release scenario and an alternative scenario.

The worst case release is highly improbable since it involves the combination of a certain set of conditions for a large release of the chemical without any employee intervention.  Because the assumptions required for the worst-case analysis are very conservative, the results likely will be very conservative. The endpoints specified for regulated toxic substances are intended to be protective of the general public. The distance to the endpoint estimated under worst-case conditions should not be considered an area in which the public would likely be in danger; instead, it is intended to provide an estimate of the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic accident. EPA intends the estimated distances to provide a basis for discussion among the regulated community, emergency respo

nders, and the public, rather a basis for any specific actions.

A release from a 20,000 gallon railcar has been identified as the worst-case release and was considered in the hazard assessment.  The catastrophic release would release approximately 204,400 lbs. of TDI. The impact distance from the worst-case scenario has been estimated using EPA's ALOHA Model.  The ALOHA Method estimates a distance to the endpoint of 0.21 mile for the worse-case release scenario. The impact distance extends beyond the facility property line. There are approximately less than two thousand sixty two people in nearby industrial and residential setting that may be within the potentially affected area.                    

The alternative scenario is an event more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and is a more realistic accident scenario.  FXI, Inc.has determined that the most likely alternative scenario for the facility is a process piping release (flange leak or failure in process line) from the process line carrying TDI from the tank to the pouring head.  The leak would release approximately 1,080 lbs of TDI.  The RMPComp Method estimates a distance to the endpoint of 0.1 mile for the alternative release scenario.  The impact distance extends beyond the facility property line. There are approximately fifty (50) people residing within the potentially affected area.



          

          

D. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

Process Safety Information: FXI, Inc.has completed a compilation of written safety information to be used in conducting the Hazard Review. The Hazard Review has been conducted using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the TDI System. 

Hazard Review: FXI, Inc.will update and revalidate the Hazard Review as necessary and every five (5) years. The Hazard Review was conducted using  the "What IF" methodology, which is one of the methodologie

s specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including one member who has expertise in the TDI System and a member knowledgeable in the specified  methodology. A system was established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operation, maintenance and other employees who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.



Operating Procedures: FXI, Inc.has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where TDI is utilized. These written operating procedures are consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the TDI system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. FXI, Inc.has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the TDI facility.



Training: FXI, Inc.will continue to provide training for each employee associated with the TDI system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.54.  Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. FXI, Inc.documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.



Mechanical Integrity: FXI, Inc. has developed a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity o

f the equipment used in the TDI process (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.

Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the TDI system components receives training at FXI, Inc. Foam Technologies every three (3) years or more often if necessary.



Compliance Audits: FXI, Inc.will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by an FXI, Inc. Foam Technologies person knowledgeable in the TDI system.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed.  FXI, Inc.will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained.



Incident Investigation: FXI, Inc.will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of TDI. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one FXI, Inc. Foam Technologies person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and FXI, Inc.will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented. Incident investigation reports will be retained for five (5) years.



E. Five-year Accident History

Within the past five years, the process has had no accidental releases that caused offsite impacts provided in the RMP rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1).



F. Emergency Response Program

FXI, Inc.has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of

protecting public health and the environment. 

This program includes the following elements: 

1. An emergency management plan, which is maintained on site and contains at FXI, Inc. Foam Technologies the following elements:

   a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;

   b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary for   

      Accidental exposures; and

   c. Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of TDI.

2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection.

3. Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and

4. Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency management plan to     

 Reflect changes at FXI, Inc.and to ensure that employees are informed of changes.



G. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

In an attempt to ensure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training will be conducted at FXI, Inc. Foam Technologies every three years on this program.  This program requires the attendance of personnel whose job is related to the TDI system.  Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires FXI, Inc.to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.
